title: Smoked Salmon
description: Nothing brings forth all the natural flavors of salmon like a good slow smoker — the taste is a gift for those who took the time to plan and prepare properly. Ideally served with bagels, cream cheese, and capers.

items.item: salmon fillets, skin on and pin bones removed

instructions: Whisk together the granulated sugar, light brown sugar, kosher salt, and crushed black peppercorns in a medium bowl.

Lay a sheet of foil on a large sheet pan, then layer plastic wrap on top. Sprinkle a third of the cure onto the plastic wrap. Lay the first fillet skin-side-down onto the cure. Sprinkle another third of the cure onto the flesh side. Place the second fillet skin-side-down on top of the first. Sprinkle the remaining cure over the top fillet.
Wrap the plastic and foil tightly around the fish to contain juices. Place another sheet pan on top and weigh it down with something heavy (like cans).
Remove from the fridge, unwrap, and thoroughly rinse the fish under cold water to remove excess cure. Pat both fillets dry with paper towels.
Whisk together the dry rub ingredients (brown sugar, coriander, paprika, peppers, and salt) in a small bowl. Pat the rub onto one or both fillets to form a thin layer, dusting off any excess.
Let the fillets dry at room temperature for 1 to 3 hours until a 'pellicle' (thin, matte-like film) forms on the surface.
Preheat your smoker to maintain a temperature of 150°F to 160°F. Use a mild wood like apple wood.
Place fillets side-by-side in the smoker, skin side down. Smoke for 1 to 3 hours until the internal temperature reaches 140°F.
Remove the fish and place it on a baking sheet. Tent with foil and let it rest for 20 to 30 minutes before serving.
